bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to John J. Moran, September 22, 1937

div1.p: Hench thanks Moran for the manuscript of his autobiography. He offers to help Moran publish his recollections in a medical history journal.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to John J. Moran, September 22, 1937
div1.opener:
Yellow fever.
September 22, 1937
Mr. John J. Moran
c/o Cia. Sunoco de Cuba, S. A.
Avenida Menocal No. 102-A
Havana, Cuba
My dear Mr. Moran:
div1.p:
You have an apology coming from me for not having answered
your very courteous letters long before this. When they arrived, I was very
rushed, and laid them aside until I had time to write you appropriately; but
we have been so rushed here that I have simply not had time to do it. I
appreciate very much indeed your great kindness in trying to help me in the
preparation of my paper for the Staff Meeting of the Mayo Clinic. I particu-
larly appreciate your going to the trouble of writing out your most interesting
experiences, and I want to thank you very much indeed for them.

Your further courtesy in sending me the three reprints is
greatly appreciated, particularly because I had not seen these before. I am
now trying to obtain these three items--- the reprint from “The Military
Surgeon”, the one from “Popular Science” and the “Roll of Honor” from the War
Department.

When I visited Mr. Kissinger and heard his own personal
story, I was immediately struck by the fact that neither you nor he, to my
knowledge, have ever published the story in your own words. Mr. Kissinger
frankly told me that he had not done so because he didn't feel literary enough.
There is no question in my mind but that your own story and that of Mr. Kissinger
certainly should be published in some journal devoted to medical history, in
order that your contribution, as presented in your own words, may be available
for future medical historians. I asked Mr. Kissinger if he would be willing
to let me help in this matter and he said that he would. I have talked to some
of my friends here whom I have interested in this story and they agree with
me that this should be done. I shall be delighted to have the real privilege
and pleasure of helping to do the same for your story. Please realize that
I have no ulterior motives whatever in this suggestion. The story should be
yours, not mine, and the only part that I would play in it would be to arrange
for its publication in a suitable medical journal, and to help the editor of
that journal in a little historical research to verify the accuracy of some
personal references. As you know, the story has not been told with complete
accuracy as far as I can find any place. Although the story is told in some
detail, nevertheless your own version of it would be most interesting and it
should be published under your own name. The preparation of this story for
a medical publication would be made in an entirely different way from that
for a lay publication. As you know, such a story as yours would have to be
jazzed up to satisfy the editor of a laymen's magazine. Therefore, the story

as prepared for a medical journal unfortunately will not bring you any
remuneration, as they do not pay for such items. I am sure that, regardless
of this, you might wish to have your story on record for all time. Should
you be willing to do this, I shall be delighted to collaborate with you
in amplifying the story that you have already written me, and I should like
to try to arrange with the editor of one of our medical historical journals
that your story and Kissinger's appear at the same time together. Each of
you will of course see the story as written by the other in order that any
apparent contradictions or differences of opinion due to faulty memory, be
corrected. I have noticed the tendency of some writers to try to give
more credit to one or the other volunteers in these experiments. I, personally,
feel that this is out of place; that all of you concerned in these experiments,
particularly you and Mr. Kissinger, deserve equal recognition and every credit
possible for your services. Regardless of the outcome and who happened to have
been bitten first and whether one was sicker than the other, the fact remains
that each of you volunteered all that you had as far as you were concerned;
and as far as I am concerned and I am sure as far as the medical profession
is concerned there can be no distinction, and I depricate as much as you do,
and as I personally know Mr. Kissinger does, the attitude of the occasional
writer who writes up the story of one to the partial exclusion of another.
Nevertheless, this is a natural mistake made by the writers who perhaps happens
to be in touch with only one of the participants in these researches. Naturally,
he knows more about that one individual and therefore cannot help but stress
his contribution.

Dr. Crenshaw, I am delighted to say, is still a member of
the Mayo Clinic Staff. He is one of our most prominent members of the staff
and you will be hearing from him shortly.
div1.closer: Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
